title: For Those Who Don’t Identify as Male or Female, Growing Acceptance—and Accommodation
text:
A growing number of states and companies are allowing people to designate their gender as “X” instead of male or female on driver’s licenses and other forms of identification.

The changes are a response to transgender Americans who don’t identify as exclusively male or female and others who feel binary gender categories don’t accurately describe them. Two years ago, Oregon became the first state to officially accommodate such residents by allowing them to select an X in the gender field of their driver’s license to convey that their gender is nonbinary or unspecified.

Since then, another eight states and the District of Columbia have followed suit, and at least six more states say they will make the change in the coming months. Nine states plus New York City allow people to change the gender field on their birth certificate to a nonbinary marker. Most states allow such changes without an explanation.

The moves are part of a broader shift toward recognizing gender-nonconforming Americans. The ride-sharing service Lyft Inc. and several major airlines this year began allowing customers to select gender-neutral pronouns on their service profiles and tickets. Mastercard Inc. recently launched a “True Name” card geared toward transgender customers that allows them to put the name of their choice on their credit card even if it doesn’t match their legal moniker.

C.P. Hoffman. Photo: Annie Tritt for The Wall Street Journal

Last month the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, the federal agency that polices workplace discrimination, told employers that they could classify workers as nonbinary when they submit pay data to the agency after learning some employers voluntarily track it that way. International law firm Baker McKenzie in June said its workforce diversity targets now include having partners and other professionals who are gender nonbinary.

“The developments are moving so fast,” said Jessica Clarke, a Vanderbilt Law School professor who studies gender identity.

The issue has spilled onto the 2020 campaign trail. Several of the Democratic presidential candidates, including Elizabeth Warren, Pete Buttigieg and Cory Booker, want the federal government to issue passports and other forms of ID with a nonbinary gender option. Canada, Germany, Australia, India and other countries offer a similar option on national identity documents. The Trump administration has blocked such efforts in courts, and the Obama administration did, too. A State Department official declined to comment on the issue, citing pending litigation.

Some state Republican lawmakers and conservative groups have tried to block the changes. “Government documents shouldn’t reflect personal opinions,” said Jonathan Keller, chief executive of the California Family Council, a religious policy group that unsuccessfully fought the change in the Golden State. “They need to reflect biological facts for identification and medical purposes.”

Matt Sharp, senior counsel at the Alliance Defending Freedom, a conservative legal group, said that such changes complicate the government’s ability to track life expectancy and diseases by gender and raise thorny issues for the enforcement of laws designed to expand opportunities for women, such as Title IX. “Does a school now have to create a new category of sports and new athletic opportunities for individuals with the X designation on their birth certificate?” he asked.

C.P. Hoffman, a 40-year-old Greenbelt, Md., attorney who identifies as nonbinary, plans to get a new driver’s license with an X in the gender field when Maryland begins issuing them Oct. 1. Mx. Hoffman, who uses the gender-neutral honorific, said showing a license to get into a bar or to join a store loyalty program has often been uncomfortable because the ID’s gender marker didn’t feel accurate.

“Having an ID that recognizes who you are is really so vital to moving through this world,” Mx. Hoffman said.

A 2016 study by the Williams Institute at the UCLA School of Law found that 0.6% of U.S. adults, about 1.4 million, identify as transgender—when gender identity is different from sex at birth—based on responses from a federal health survey; it didn’t specify the share that is gender nonconforming. A Pew Research survey earlier this year found that about a third of Gen Z and a quarter of millennials know someone who goes by gender-neutral pronouns.

Akiva Wolberg, who is gender nonconforming, switched to a District of Columbia driver’s license with an X gender marker two years ago. Photo: Annie Tritt for The Wall Street Journal

In some states, hundreds or thousands of residents have already applied for gender-nonbinary driver’s licenses, said Ian Grossman, a vice president at the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators, the trade group for state departments of motor vehicles.

Prof. Clarke said that the legalization of same-sex marriage greatly diminished the number of legal arrangements that rely on categorizing a person as a man or a woman, leaving few legal reasons to restrict people to two gender categories. She noted that, instead of explicitly recognizing a third gender marker, some municipalities have made it optional to include any kind of sex designation on documents.

Akiva Wolberg, who is gender nonconforming, switched to a District of Columbia driver’s license with an X gender marker two years ago. The 31-year-old database administrator said that it hasn’t created any problems and that most people who view the ID don’t seem to notice it is different.

Mx. Wolberg said those who oppose the ID changes are overlooking the fact that transgender people’s licenses don’t achieve the stated function of identity documents. “If a lot of people think I look like a guy, and my license says F, then the F is obviously not doing a very good job of proving who I say I am, which is the entire point of an ID.”

—Jennifer Calfas contributed to this article.
